A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to answer a general question on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experience or other. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experience; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the question.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1974, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years. If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked pioneer questions has exactly the same experiences or memories to answer. Some of the questions have only to do with experiences which may prove impossible for you to answer so don't worry about answering them. If there is not enough space to answer all the questions, don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in that province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

The home I lived in was located at the base of the mountain, north of town. It was a small house made of logs and had a thatched roof. The walls were made of adobe bricks and the floor was covered with straw. The house had two rooms, one for sleeping and one for cooking. The only source of light was a kerosene lamp. The house was heated by a wood stove.

23. In there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount? On the 1st of July, 1903 myself and two of my neighbors took our wives and families by wagon to a point about six miles south of Butte Creek. We started early from Butte Creek and traveled until that day and it rained almost all day and after the shower we started for home and when got our own place started to rain again we got a lot of rain and just before we got to Canada

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

The town I lived in was called Butte Creek. It was located north of Butte Creek and west of the town of Butte Creek. The town was named after the creek that runs through it.
25. When was the first car used in the community? 1914 by Black Speckler

26. If you owned a car before 1914, then did you buy it? What make? I bought a Model T Ford in 1916.

27. Where was your trading centre? How far from your home? Saskatoon, 172 miles

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.) The CPR came through in 1910 when the railroad came through Vanley. Had a little store. That's where we did our trading as it was only four and a half miles by team and buggy.

29. How often did you shop in the early days? About once a month

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays? About 1915

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? We started buying by mail order since the pioneer period. Our first purchase was a half of our purchase and half our purchase remained as our family first purchase.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it? 1911

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision? Fall 1902.
25. When was the first car used in the community? 1914 by Black Spider

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns, opportunities, better means of travel, etc.) Yes, we continued through Vanney's store. That's where we did our trading as it was only four and a half miles by team and buggy.
